title: Too-wide spans for function arguments with unsatisfied trait bounds

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur. 
-->
Currently rustc outputs very wide spans for missing trait impls in function signatures (the spans cover the whole function instead of the offending arguments only).

Given the following code: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=910ee19aff7219ada0a39c619137aafc

```rust
struct A;

trait T {
    type Item;
}

fn foo(a: <A as T>::Item) {
    let _ = 1;
}
```

The current output is:

```
   Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground)
error[E0277]: the trait bound `A: T` is not satisfied
 --> src/lib.rs:7:1
  |
7 | / fn foo(a: <A as T>::Item) {
8 | |     let _ = 1;
9 | | }
  | |_^ the trait `T` is not implemented for `A`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `playground`

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally the output should look like:

```
error[E0277]: the trait bound `A: Signature` is not satisfied
  --> robusta-example/src/lib.rs:70:13
   |
7  |             a: <A as T>::Item
   |                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ the trait `T` is not implemented for `A`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `playground`

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```

<!--
If the problem is not self-explanatory, please provide a rationale for the
change.
-->

For example, compare rustc output to something like:
```rust
struct A;

trait T {
    type Item;
}

fn bar(a: A) {
    let _: <A as T>::Item;
}
```

```
   Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground)
error[E0277]: the trait bound `A: T` is not satisfied
  --> src/lib.rs:12:12
   |
7  |     let _: <A as T>::Item;
   |            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ the trait `T` is not implemented for `A`

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `playground`

To learn more, run the command again with --verbose.
```

<!--
If dramatically different output is caused by small changes, consider also
adding them here.

If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions. The output might also be
different depending on the Edition.
-->
Currently the output is the same in stable, beta and nightly.
